A federal appeals court unanimously supported the Bush administration's right to conceal the names of those from whom it seeks advice.
The case began four years ago when Vice President Cheney's energy policy task force solicited opinions from private energy executives.
In response, two groups, the Sierra Club and Judicial Watch, promptly sued for disclosure.
Our correspondent, Farai Chideya, spoke with Christopher Edley, dean and professor of law at the University of California-Berkeley.
Let me make sure I have this right.

This case bounced from an appellate court to the Supreme Court, which sent it back to the appellate court, and the first time the appellate court upheld the judge's order to reveal names of those who advised Vice President Cheney on energy policy.
Now why did this same court unanimously rule in favor of the administration?

It's a fascinating decision because it restrikes the balance between the White House concern with what it asserts is its interest in being able to consult broadly within the administration, but also with outsiders, on the one hand, and the view of some public interest groups that there ought to be as much sunshine as possible on the way the White House does business.
Do you think the court was right in this ruling, or was it right the previous time?
I actually think it was right in this ruling.

First, let me emphasize that this ruling was what's called an en banc ruling, so it involved all of the judges on the DC Circuit Court of Appeals, Democrats and Republicans alike, and they ruled unanimously.
So that in itself is quite significant.

But the second point is that this opinion, unlike several others that judges have issued, seems to me to demonstrate much more sophistication in appreciating what it's like to be in government trying to make complicated public policy decisions.
I'm actually of the view, having served in two administrations at the White House, that too much sunshine can actually inhibit sound decisionmaking.
The problem here is not that the public is unaware of who met with whom.
The problem is that a lot of people in the public, myself included, don't like the policy choices that were made.
The remedy to that is not forcing full disclosure of every meeting and every conversation, or putting TV cameras in every office in the West Wing.

The remedy to that is to elect different people to political office, and also to see to it that when decisions are then delegated from the White House to administrative agencies, that they obey the law in allowing full participation at that stage.
Why is it important that any presidential administration be allowed to withhold certain information from the public?
Look, here's the situation.
If I'm sitting there working for the president trying to put together a legislative proposal, I didn't come into the job knowing everything about everything.

I've got to have an ability to get smart, not only by consulting with people who are inside the administration, and that's clearly permissible under the statutes, but I've also got to be able to pick up the phone or have meetings with people who are outside the administration to get smart.
Now the objection is, well, but what happens if a guy in that White House job only talks to people who are on one side of the issue instead of talking to people on multiple sides of the issue?
Well, that, it seems to me, is the difference between politics and judging.
If you're in a court of law, the judge, the jury are obliged to hear both sides of the issue.
But once we have an election and we've put people in positions of power, expecting them to exercise some discretion, you've got to expect that they aren't necessarily gonna act like judges.
They're gonna act like what they are, and that is political officials.
Christopher Edley is dean and professor of law at UC-Berkeley's Boalt School of Law.
Thanks again for joining us.
Take care.
Farai Chideya, NPR News.

The bigger group, though, are the Republicans in control of Congress who are worried for the political fallout.

There are points on the timeline of American military history where the tables turned.
The 2007 surge in the current war in Iraq is a recent example.
William Tecumseh Sherman's march to the sea in 1864 is another.
The Union general's campaign, after the capture of Atlanta, Georgia, to the taking of Savannah, has provided an unending source of material for Civil War historians, including Noah Andre Trudeau.
Longtime listeners know him as Andy, our Oscar music guy.
But Trudeau is an award-winning writer, and ""Southern Storm: Sherman's March to the Sea"" is his latest tome.
He's in the studio.
It's really nice to see you again, Andy.
Great to see you, Liane.
Paint that picture for us.

Atlanta is burning, Lincoln has been re-elected president, and William Tecumseh Sherman convinces the president and General Grant that he can take a huge contingent of men and arms, cease communication, and march to Savannah.
How did he convince them?
He counted a lot on his friendship with Grant.
This really was the partnership that I think won the Civil War, these two men - Grant in charge in the East, Sherman in charge in the West - intimately trusting each other.
Grant had come in and said, what we've got to do is smash the enemy's armies.
Here is Sherman in September of 1864 saying, you know, I think the best thing I can do is turn my back on the biggest enemy army near me and march to the sea.
You know, to me, the great success of this campaign was the logistical achievement.
He had to move 60,000 men, almost 3,000 wagons, and - what blows my mind - 5,000 cattle across 300 miles, seven major river crossings, with no bridges, and he did it.
He waged total war.
Beans and bullets is a phrase that is used.
Was total destruction in Georgia the goal or the byproduct?
It was a byproduct.
Sherman was really trying to do a number of things.
On a tactical level, he was moving 60,000 men from Atlanta to the sea where they would be more useful to Grant.
On a practical level, he had to feed these guys.
Ultimately, he was really showing to Southern civilians that the Confederacy could not protect them.
And he was showing to Southern soldiers that no one was protecting their loved ones and the sooner they ended this war, the better.
In feeding and supplying his men, did that get out of hand?
Yes and no. You know, if you abandoned your house, it would likely get looted.
If somebody fired a gun from your house, your house was probably toast.

But for a lot of them, especially the ones who wrote a lot of the memoirs, when you really look past the story they're telling, you realize that after Sherman's army left, they still had their home, they still had some foodstuffs.
I mean, there was no widespread starvation in Georgia in the winter of 1864-65.
So, yes, it had a tremendous impact, but it was not the kind of catastrophic scouring operation that I think people often assume it was.
